questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following statements about inverted papilloma is false?

options.b: Arises from the lateral wall of nose
options.d: Presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and epistaxis

questions.explanation:
Inverted papilloma is more common in males. 409 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 2: A 46-year-old man presented with left-sided nasal blockage and discharge for 3 years. On 
anterior rhinoscopy, a pale, red polypoidal mass is seen in the left nostril. He was diagnosed 
with inverted papilloma. Which of the following statements is false about the management of 
his condition?

options.d: MRI is the first imaging modality in follow-up

questions.explanation: Radiotherapy is not advised in inverted papilloma since it may induce malignancy. Option A: Endoscopic approach is preferred to surgical resection. Option C: There is a high rate of recurrence of inverted papillomas. Option D: MRI is the first imaging modality to perform during follow up.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following is the most common malignant tumor of the nasal cavity?
questions.explanation:
Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor of the nasal cavity, seen in about 
80% of cases.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following is also known as nose picker’s carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
Squamous cell carcinoma of the nasal cavity arising from the nasal septum is called nose picker’s 
cancer. Option A: Inverted papilloma is also known as transitional cell papilloma or Ringertz tumor or 
Schneiderian papilloma. Option B: Basal cell carcinoma is also known as rodent ulcer. Option D: Esthesioneuroblastoma is also known as olfactory neuroblastoma.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 15-year-old presented with a cherry red, polypoidal mass detected on anterior rhinoscopy. 
Biopsy of the mass suggested that it originated from the olfactory neural epithelium. Which of 
the following is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario suggests the diagnosis of esthesioneuroblastoma. It arises from the 
olfactory epithelium of the upper third of the nose.

questions.question:
Question 6: A patient is planned for surgical resection of esthesioneuroblastoma. Which of the following 
statements is false about the same?

options.d: Lymph node metastasis does not occur

questions.explanation: Lymph node metastasis occurs in 10-15% of the cases.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following is the most common site for osteomas?
questions.explanation:
Osteomas are most commonly seen in the frontal sinus followed by ethmoid and maxillary 
sinuses. They remain asymptomatic and are incidentally found on x-rays. Treatment is required only when 
they cause obstructive symptoms or pressure effects. 410 
Sold by @itachibot The image given shows the x-ray image of an osteoma in the frontal sinus.

questions.question:
Question 10: A patient is referred to the ENT OPD with left-sided nasal obstruction, disfigurement of the 
face, and displacement of his left eye. Imaging of paranasal sinuses shows an ill-defined 
expanding lesion with ground glass appearance in the maxillary sinus. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The diagnosis is fibrous dysplasia. A ground-glass appearance in CT or x-ray is characteristic of 
fibrous dysplasia. In fibrous dysplasia, bone is replaced by fibrous tissue. The most common site is the maxillary 
sinus, followed by the ethmoid and frontal sinuses. It can present with disfigurement of the face, nasal obstruction, and displacement of the eye. The x-ray image below shows a ground-glass appearance present in the left maxillary sinus due to 
fibrous dysplasia. The lesion is not well demarcated and merges with the surrounding area. There 
is orbital displacement on the left side. 412 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: Which of the following histological varieties is the most common among paranasal sinus 
carcinomas?
questions.explanation: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor of the paranasal sinuses.

questions.question:
Question 12: 406 
Sold by @itachibot Where is squamous cell carcinoma most commonly found in the paranasal sinuses?
questions.explanation:
Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common in the maxillary sinuses followed in turn by 
ethmoids, frontal and sphenoid sinuses.

questions.question:
Question 13: A carpenter was diagnosed with sinonasal carcinoma and planned for surgical resection. 
Which of the following histological varieties would be most likely in this case?
questions.explanation:
Adenocarcinoma is the most common variety in this case. Workers of the furniture industry or 
woodworkers develop adenocarcinoma. It is most commonly found in the ethmoid sinuses and upper nasal cavity. Workers engaged in nickel refining may develop squamous cell carcinoma and anaplastic 
carcinoma.

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following is an early feature of maxillary carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
Blood-tinged nasal discharge is an early feature of maxillary carcinoma. Other early features include: • Nasal stuffiness 413 
Sold by @itachibot • Facial paraesthesias • Pain • Epiphora. These symptoms may be missed or simply treated as sinusitis. Option B: Lymphatic spread occurs in the late stages of the disease. Among the cervical lymph 
nodes, submandibular and upper jugular lymph nodes are enlarged. Option C: Proptosis is a late feature that occurs after the invasion of the orbit. Option D: Dental pain is a late feature that occurs due to expansion of the alveolus after the tumor 
spreads inferiorly.

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following conditions is classified using Ohngren’s classification?
questions.explanation:
Ohngren’s classification is used for maxillary carcinoma. An imaginary plane is drawn, extending between medial canthus of eye and the angle of mandible. Ohngren's line(below image): Growths situated above this plane (suprastructural) have a poorer prognosis than those below it 
(infrastructural).

questions.question:
Question 16: 407 
Sold by @itachibot A 43-year-old factory worker presents to you with nasal obstruction, cheek swelling, and 
diplopia. The ENT resident suspects maxillary carcinoma and uses the following image to 
classify the same. Which one of the following classification systems are used?
questions.explanation:
Ledermann’s classification is used to classify maxillary carcinoma in this case. It uses two horizontal lines of Sebileau; one passing through the floors of orbits and the other 
through floors of antra. 414 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 17: You have a patient with maxillary sinus carcinoma. Which of the following lymph nodes will 
be most commonly involved?
questions.explanation:
The submandibular and jugulodigastric nodes are the most commonly involved in maxillary sinus 
carcinoma. Maxillary and ethmoid sinus drain primarily into retropharyngeal nodes but, these nodes are 
inaccessible for palpation.

questions.question:

shows that the tumor has eroded into the floor and medial wall of the orbit and the frontal 
sinus. Which of the following is the best management strategy? 408

staging is T4 by AJCC classification. T3 and T4 lesions are treated by combined modalities of radiation and surgery. Radiation in such
